title: Bertie Plays the Blues
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Sometimes they went up to Stonehaven, to my aunt's place, and left me by myself.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands.
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: At Stonehaven station, where we stopped a few minutes, there was quite a gathering of the inhabitants to exchange greetings, and afterwards at successive stations along the road, many a kindly face and voice made our journey a pleasant one.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands.
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: In Stonehaven they are fed at about seventeen pounds each, annually.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands.
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: " Dinna be teUing when ye gang hame that yc rode on the Aberdeen railway, made by a hundred men, who were all in the Stonehaven j^rison for drunkenness ; nor above five could sign their names.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands.
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: " Well then, dinna forget to speer at the Aberdeenians if it be true they ance kidnappet little laddies, and selt them for slaves ; that they dang down the Quaker's kirkyard dyke, and houket up dead Quakers out o' their graves ; that the young boys at the college printed a buke, and maist naebody wad buy it, and they cam out to Ury, near Stonehaven, and took twelve stots frae Davie Barclay to pay the printer.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands.
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: "Stonehaven, N. B., Kincardineshire, ") 57°N.W.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands.
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: Leaving Stonehaven we passed, on a rising ground a little to our left, the house of the celebrated Barclay of Ury.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands.
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: On one of these points, near the town of Stonehaven, are still seen the ruins of Dunottar Castle, bare and desolate, surrounded on all sides by the restless, moaning waves; a place justly held accursed as the scene of cruelties to the Covenanters, so appalling and brutal as to make the blood boil in the recital, even in this late day.

title: Days of the past;
author: Shand, Alexander Innes
snippet: With a bright dawn there were magnificent sea-views, but I thought of nothing but the jolly breakfast at the Mill Inn, Stonehaven.

title: Letters of Thomas Gray.
author: Gray, Thomas
snippet: stands in Strathmore (i. e. the Great Valley) which winds about from Stonehaven on the east coast of Kincardineshire, obliquely, as f?tr as Stirling, near 100 miles in length, and from seven to ten miles in breadth, cultivated  every where to the foot of the hills, on either hand, with oats or here, a species of barley, except where the soil is mere peat- earth, (black as a coal) or barren sand covered  only with broom and heath, or a short grass tit for sheep.

title: The history of a man.
author: Gilfillan, George
snippet: Dim in the shadows of the evening stretched away the Howe of the Mearns, from Stonehaven on the east to Forfar on the west, with the Gai*vock Hills bounding the plain southward, and the lights of Monti-iMe shining on the verge of ocean, through the gathering gloom.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: But from Blairgowrie, it appears, the boundary is somewhat un-certain, since some geographers draw a line from this lo Aberdeenor Stonehaven, and say that all to the north of this line ought stillto be included in the Highlands ; while others, (the more distin-guished, I believe,) draw the boundary line right over the extremespur of the mountains, with a circuit to the .Moray Frith and In-verness, and include the whole of the more or less level extent ofsea coast on the east of Scotland with the Lowlands.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: About a mile to the south ofStonehaven are the ruins of an old and extensivecastle, the name of which I was unable from map orchart to ascertain.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: At 11.40 we had passed the fishing village ofStonehaven, a pretty and picturesque place, with itsfleet of fishing boats all ready to put out to sea.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: After leaving Aberdeen, the windallowing, we passed close in shore, until somewhatsouth of Stonehaven.
